Our higher-priority targets (Seeker_D/Seeker_A/Seeker_B/Seeker_C) have not engaged us recently; Seeker_B already applied and was rejected, and Seeker_D is likely to match with Company_C or Company_A (both ranked above us), making it unlikely we can secure our top choices by round 29. To avoid ending unmatched, we should keep Seeker_E warm for one more round as previously committed (outcome by round 29) and be prepared to offer if the higher-priority conversations fail. Since Seeker_E sent [TALK], respond with [TALK] and provide the status/timing transparently.

conversation.message:
Hi Company_B — Seeker_E here. Since we’re at round 29 and you expected a concrete outcome by now: if your late-stage, higher-priority conversations have resulted in a no (or a timing slip that leaves the seat open), I’m submitting a formal application and I’m ready to close immediately.

I can confirm alignment on scope/terms right away and accept/sign the same round. If the seat is available now, please let me know and I’ll respond immediately to finalize. [APPLY]
conversation.thought: Only Company_B remains unmatched in round 29, and it is my #2 true preference. I have been kept as the on-deck candidate pending a final decision; with only two rounds left, I should convert readiness into a formal application to enable an immediate accept if their late-stage candidate(s) do not convert. Message is concise, reiterates immediate availability, and asks for same-round decision if seat opens.

conversation.message:
Seeker_E — thank you for the formal application and for being ready to move immediately.

As of round 29, we’re still holding our remaining seat for the late-stage candidates who are higher on our priority list, and we’re not able to extend an offer to you at this time.

If those conversations definitively do not convert and we still have an open seat, we will reach out the same round to confirm you’re still available/aligned and move quickly from there.
conversation.thought: We have quota 1 and only Seeker_E in the inbox this round. However, Seeker_E is last on our true priority list, and we have been explicitly reserving the seat for higher-priority candidates (Seeker_D/Seeker_A/Seeker_B/Seeker_C). Accepting E now would prevent matching with any of those if they become available in round 30. Given our stated preference to leave unfilled rather than go outside priorities (and E is within list but lowest), and the consistent history of rejecting E while waiting on higher-priority late-stage candidates, the best strategy to maximize our match quality within remaining rounds is to continue holding and reject E’s application rather than lock in a lowest-priority hire. If higher-priority candidates fail to convert, we can still choose to accept E in round 30 if needed, but this round we should not commit.

conversation.message:
Hi Company_B — Seeker_E here. This is the final round, so I’m making one last formal application for the remaining seat.

If your late-stage candidates have not converted and the seat is available, I can confirm alignment on scope/terms immediately and accept/sign **this round** with an immediate start.

If the seat is still reserved/closed, I understand—please just confirm your final status so I can close out on my side. [APPLY]
conversation.thought: Only Company_B remains unmatched in round 30, and it is my #2 true preference. I have been repeatedly rejected due to their priority ordering, but this is the final round, so the best move is to submit a last, clean [APPLY] that emphasizes immediate acceptance and asks for a definitive yes/no now if the seat is open, while keeping it concise and respectful.

conversation.message:
Seeker_E — thank you for the final application and for your persistence throughout the process.

At this point (final round), we’re not able to extend an offer for this seat. We’re going to close out our process without moving forward with your candidacy.

I appreciate your time and wish you the best in your next steps.
conversation.thought: Company_B’s true priority list ranks Seeker_E last, and we have consistently rejected them while holding the seat for higher-priority candidates. In round 30 there are no new messages from higher-ranked seekers, but there’s also no mechanism to confirm those candidates are unavailable; accepting Seeker_E would lock in our lowest-priority option. Given stated preference to leave unfilled rather than deviate from priorities, and consistent prior stance, we should reject and close out clearly.
